I'm still not clear why you would want to do this. To my mind, test
isolation means that you don't need g1(). It doesn't add anything new.
It probably suffers from being a toy example that doesn't help me
understand why you would want to do this.

If you write a method

@Test
public void g() {
f1();
f2();
}

the calls to f1() and f2() are just normal Java method calls. It is
the JUnit Runner that understands the expected parameter of the @Test
annotation, but that gets lost when you (in the test body) are
invoking methods. Perhaps you need to read about the Runner API and
roll your own custom Runner, but I can't be sure at this stage.

Cheers,

James
